Award.AwardTitle: RUI/Collaborative Research: The Effects of Age related Changes in Muscle Extracellular Matrix on Muscle Performance and Gait

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Muscle extracellular matrix, the connective tissue surrounding muscle fibers, has been shown to change with age, disuse, and neuromuscular disease. These conditions cause muscle fibrosis-a pathological increase in muscle extra cellular matrix. This work aims to understand the basic functional implications of muscle fibrosis at the level of tissues, organs and whole organisms. In addition to examining the mechanics of the system at various levels of biological organization, the project will combine complementary modeling and experimental approaches to better understand the fundamental properties of fibrotic muscle. The broad scientific goal is to elucidate the implications of fibrosis for muscle function, and to examine how such changes relate to deficiencies in gait and movement. In addition, outreach efforts will broaden research experiences for underrepresented groups and aid in the development of interdisciplinary lesson plans in high-school science curricula.

The extracellular matrix (ECM) of skeletal muscle is known to play a critical role in the passive elasticity and stiffness of muscle fibers and fascicles, but it remains unclear how variation in the properties of the ECM are likely to affect contractile performance, in vivo function, and gait. The project will integrate empirical studies using a well-established animal model system for aging (F344xBN rats) with modeling approaches to examine how the remodeling of the ECM impacts performance. The first objective will be to use isolated muscle fascicles and laser diffraction to characterize how age-related fibrosis alters the capacity of muscle fibers to produce mechanical work. The hypothesis is that increased ECM stiffness limits a muscle's ability to perform mechanical work by limiting radial expansion of muscle fibers and fascicles. The second objective is to use high-speed x-ray imaging to examine how muscle fibrosis affects muscle performance during normal locomotion. The project will test the hypothesis that increased muscle stiffness restricts muscle to operate at relatively short lengths, resulting in decreased force production in vivo. Finally, an examination of the effects of increasing passive stiffness on gait mechanics. Using empirical data from rats to drive forward dynamic gait simulations, the PIs will explicitly link the isolated effects of passive muscle stiffness on joint mechanics and whole-body performance. By integrating empirical studies of tissues, organs and whole organisms with model simulations the work will elucidate how variation in ECM properties affects performance across levels of biological organization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the next two decades the proportion of the U.S. population that is older than 65 will exceed 20%. It is therefore imperative to find ways to allow our aging population to maintain the highest possible quality of life. For many seniors, the loss of mobility can negatively affect physical, psychological and social health. Moreover, a regular exercise regime has been shown to be the single most important determinant of quality of life in the elderly. Despite the clear benefits of regular exercise, older individuals face an additional metabolic burden during exercise which may act as a motivational barrier to maintaining an active lifestyle. To date, explanations for why locomotion becomes more expensive with age have proven insufficient. The efforts undertaken during this award were aimed at understanding how changes to the mechanical structures within skeletal muscle tissue can impact contractile performance and gait. We used a well-established animal of aging (Rats) to explore how the increased deposition of collagen within the muscle constrains the ability of muscles to produce force, change length and generate mechanical work. Much of the work accomplished through this award was based on an interdisciplinary approach which combines mathematical modeling and experimental measurements to not only discover new mechanisms within our focal model system but to also produce generalizable results that extend to other organisms and other conditions where similar structural changes are observed. We have discovered that in old muscles, the increased stiffness of the tissue associated with increased connective tissue content compromised the muscle?s ability to change shape which in turn limits the ability to contract forcefully. We also found that as a muscle gets weaker while tendons get stiffer, the ability to cycle mechanical energy through a tendon (which has been shown to reduce the metabolic cost of movement) is compromised. Finally, we showed that muscles with extensive collagen within the tissue are unable to shorten to the same degree as healthy, young muscles thereby reducing their capacity to generate mechanical work. All three of these discoveries provide novel mechanisms that may help explain the additional metabolic burden associated with movement in older individuals. In addition to the scientific impact of this work, funds were used to establish a rigorous and effective outreach program aimed increasing the diversity and inclusivity of the STEM work force by engaging young students (2ndgraders and 7thgraders) from underrepresented minority groups. In addition, we established a partnership with the Graduate Division at UC Irvine and supported six undergraduate students (over three summers) who participated in a gateway program aimed at providing independent research experience as well as training needed for successful entry into PhD programs.
